Time for VT to drop mandates GOVERNOR-ELECT YOUNGKIN AND ATTORNEY GENERAL-ELECT MIYARES TO CHALLENGE CENTERS FOR MEDICARE & MEDICAID SERVICES‚Äô VACCINE MANDATE  RICHMOND::: VA ‚Äì Governor-elect Glenn Youngkin and Attorney General-elect Jason Miyares today announced their intent to challenge the unconstitutiona l vaccine mandate imposed by President Biden‚Äôs Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS).  ‚ÄúThe COVID-19 pandemic has caused heartbreaking health::: societal::: and economic loss and suffering throughout the Commonwealth and the United States. Our children have experienced severe learning loss and developmental challenges that will last decades::: strained and stressed hospital systems are suffering from an historic staffing crisis::: and a crippled supply chain has driven up Virginians‚Äô cost of living.  ‚ÄúInstead of supporting state and local governments‚Äô efforts to protect the lives and livelihoods of their citizens::: the Biden administration has resorted to unlawful vaccine mandates that force hardworking Virginians to walk away from their paychecks. President Biden's CMS mandate::: ignores the hospital systems' long-establishe d policies designed to keep staff and patients safe and threatens the tenure of essential medical personnel at a time when staffing shortages threaten the health and safety of Virginians.  ‚ÄúWhile we believe that the vaccine is a critical tool in the fight against COVID-19::: we strongly believe that the Federal government cannot impose its will and restrict the freedoms of Americans and that Virginia is at its best when her people are allowed to make the best decisions for their families or businesses.  ‚ÄúAfter the January 15th inauguration::: the Commonwealth of Virginia will quickly move to protect Virginians‚Äô freedoms and challenge President Biden‚Äôs unlawful CMS::: OSHA::: and Head Start vaccine mandates. Removing some of the staffing barriers to our hospitals::: will provide much needed relief for our overworked medical professionals.‚Äù

column3: Perhaps it is time for health administrators like him to seriously reconsider and reevaluate the mandatory masking policy based on current data on the dashboard. Low weekly case numbers (on campus) and a decreasing severity (an overwhelming percentage of the student body and professors are vaccinated) suggest these measures are no longer needed and can be loosened. The university enforced the measures they felt they needed to early on::: but at this point these measures are becoming increasingly unnecessary. Especially considering their predications on contradictions (a small grad-level class of 4 people is a health risk::: but a full football game is not). Most places in Blacksburg do not require masks and despite that there hasn‚Äôt been a surge in cases amongst Tech Students going to and crowding in TOTS::: Kroger::: or other local bars and businesses. People say ‚Äúlook at the county data‚Äù::: but Tech numbers::: despite the fact that Tech students interact with the Townies and visit stores and restaurants around the county (often without a mask)::: have not gone up much. Also one cannot ignore the large numbers of students openly ignoring the mandate in Newman and while walking around in the dining halls::: the measures at this point are just being increasingly disregarded (and despite that::: the numbers are still low). At this point the available mask infrastructure doesn‚Äôt help the matter either; if students forget or accidentally drop their masks there is no other alternative but for students to pick a used one off the ground (which I have observed that many are already doing; black masks are littered across campus)::: and I can assure you picking a dirty used mask off the ground is far less ‚Äúhygienic‚Äù than wearing no mask. The mask policies do not reflect the current realities of November::: 2021. They did not in September of 2021 and certainly do not today.

column19: Given the purpose of Columbus Day::: this is a bit ironic of Virginia Tech::: which prides itself on inclusivity. It was always meant to recognize the work::: sacrifice::: and contributions of immigrants-\-\fir st Italian Americans::: and later more broadly to all immigrants. The first nationally recognized Columbus Day came in 1892 following the lynching of 11 Italian immigrants. It was nearly a century later when Columbus Day became a federal holiday::: due in large part to lobbying efforts of the Knights of Columbus::: a Catholic service organization. While Christopher Columbus was a central symbol for the organization and the day::: the celebration was never meant to be about Columbus::: but rather recognize the work::: sacrifice::: and contributions of immigrants. The popular emphasis on Columbus is the result of ignorance::: xenophobia::: and anti-Catholic sentiment: "if we focus on the man:::" the Anglo-Protestan t majority reasoned::: "we can appease the minority factions without acknowledging the meaning of the day." So along came school children coloring pictures of the Nina::: Pinta::: and Santa Maria. Of course::: that plan backfired and Columbus the man was demonized. And here we are. Ironically::: rather than educating about the true meaning of the holiday-\-\whereb y they could have been a leader in using the occasion to acknowledge the contributions of their own international community-\-\Virg inia Tech bought into the xenophobic::: anti-Catholic narrative. Way to be inclusive::: Virginia Tech.

column4: How about allowing for therapeutics? Medications that when given early are successful in treating COVID patients. With breakthrough infections the vaccine cannot do it all. We can walk and chew gum at same time. Why doesn‚Äôt the CDC recognize antibodies/ natural immunity? We can get free COVID vaccines::: free COVID tests::: but have to pay for antibody testing. Why? Some say natural immunity isn‚Äôt long-lasting (even though study after study proves it is). Apparently::: neither is immunity with vaccines since a booster is needed after 6 months. Seems testing for antibodies would be the most effective means of ascertaining safety from virus.  I graduated from nursing school in 1985. AIDS was a major health issue. There was 0% survivability then. Zero. I went to work in a white uniform and blue sweater I laundered at home even though I was surrounded by blood::: bodily fluids and sharp things all shift. Gloves were not available for patient care. HIV was not yet separated from AIDS. It was not affecting only one demographic. I took care of babies and toddlers who were diagnosed with AIDS who had zero chance of survival. Good thing we didn‚Äôt wait for a vaccine (that::: btw::: Dr. Fauci was working on). Good medications/ therapeutics were developed::: thanks be to God. Now HIV/AIDS is no longer a death sentence. More than 35 yrs later::: still no AIDS vaccine::: but patients who are HIV/AIDS positive not only survive::: but thrive::: because of good therapeutics/ medications. The same can be done for COVID 19.

column1: Mental Health Initiatives Coordinator for Hokie Wellness::: Swathi Prabhu::: talks about the Mindful Campus Practices::: a series of short::: five-minute guided mindfulness practice recordings that combine imagery::: sound::: and other senses such as smell and feel. Cadets have been here since 1872. That's why the Corps of Cadets is the first organization we are celebrating as we launch an 18-month celebration of our Sesquicentennial.  Follow along with the Corps of Cadets on Twitter (https://twitter.com/VTCorpsofCadets) and Instagram (https://www.instagram.com/vtcorpsofcadets) throughout the month as they share their reflections of the past 150 years and look ahead to the future. ---------- Every cadet::: past and present::: has had a role in the 150-year legacy of Virginia Tech. Their shared history and the Corps of Cadets‚Äô story will come to life through a film created and produced by the Institute of Creativity::: Arts::: and Technology to be projected onto the facade of Lane Hall.  Blending past and present::: tradition and technology::: the magical event runs for three nights only::: Sep 10-12. The 12-minute film will begin at 8:30 p.m. each night and repeat until 10 p.m. Rain location is the Cube inside the Moss Arts Center.  Learn more ‚û°Ô∏è vtcc.vt.edu/150years #vt150

column1: It's been two years::: but the kitchens of Virginia Tech Dining Services' on-campus dining halls once again hosted kids donning chef's hats and personalized chef's coats looking to develop their cooking chops during Culinary Camp. Culinary Camp is a five-day youth camp::: and in Culinary Camp 100::: Virginia Tech chefs worked with eight kids::: ages 10 to 14::: teaching them basic cooking techniques::: nutrition::: food safety::: and how to make a fan favorite::: Buffalo Cauliflower Tacos from the Grillfield food truck. In learning how to make the tacos::: campers learned knife skills while chopping cauliflower::: and then were split into groups to tackle the other components‚Äìmixing up the tempura batter::: buffalo sauce::: creamy southern coleslaw::: as well as using the deep fryer to make the chips and crispy golden nuggets of tempura-battered cauliflower. column3: FYI to parents who are upset about this overreach to force the V on their student:  VT offered the Religious Exemption form or the Medical Exemption form. Your student has it thru the link in their VT email about the Aug 6 requirement so plz talk to them. Just because VT doesn‚Äôt publicize the form on FB to share the option with as many people as they can doesn‚Äôt mean students didn‚Äôt receive it. Legally they have to. It‚Äôs not a VT option::: It‚Äôs VA state law to have a religious exemption for anyyyyy V.  Plus VT admitted in a spring email newsletter to families that they could not require the V because it only has Emergency Use Authorization. It‚Äôs only because the AG came out in April and gave the green light to turn a blind eye that they decided to mandate it anyway!  This is what the Virginia state code says: 12VAC5-110-80. Exemptions from immunization requirements. A. Religious and medical exemptions. No certificate of immunization shall be required of any student for admission to school if: 1. The student or his parent or guardian submits a notarized Certificate of Religious Exemption (Form CRE 1)::: to the admitting official of the school to which the student is seeking admission. Form CRE 1 is an affidavit stating that the administration of immunizing agents conflicts with the student's religious tenets or practices. The form is available on the Division of Immunization website at www dot doe dot virginia dot gov and then look under support.  But obviously it‚Äôs ideal to just use the VT form form provided for the exemption.

column15: Dr. Sands::: I'd like to ask why you decided to skip the very important panel discussion yesterday? I hope you got an opportunity to at least watch it. A few points: Dr. O'Dell is looking for a milestone of 75% maxes...is that also your feeling regarding opening the classrooms? Dr. Hagerford explained how wonderful the students did in the spring::: you even had graduation ceremonies...wh y the push? Dr. Shushock::: you and I spoke about a month and a half ago::: you personally said to me that you had 2 college aged children and were very much hoping there would be no mandate..How are you feeling now? Mr. Mulhare..we spoke recently::: you mentioned that VT is offering incentives for teachers to return to campus..How is that going? Dr. Sands..Dean Learman said that those students who chose to not get maxed should talk with students that have and if convinced::: someone will be waiting behind them with the dance. Do you really think that was the best wording? You just scared the heck out of more students. Also::: not one of the people on the panel could back up any of their statistics. It would have been nice to have references where students and parents could read the same information they were spouting. Now you must understand that every parent went and did their own research on what was said and it was mostly inaccurate. Dr. Sands::: Do you find it odd that you had less than 200 people watching::: maybe they are tired of your bullying. Mr. Mulhare stated mandating employees of VT is not an option at this time. You have also said it was illegal. Do you think that maybe explaining to those who may not be aware that a RE or ME is also an option for students should have been mentioned...or does that not fit your agenda? Lastly::: why won't you make a decision on opening the classrooms? Is that because you cannot get enough professors to come back?...In the meantime you have no problem taking the money for football tix and opening Lane. Ut Prosim..that I may serve::: who exactly are you serving now? You are not listening to the students who want to go back into the classrooms instead of watching You Tube videos::: you are not taking the time to address parents' concerns::: heck::: you are not even listening to the Fox Delta Alpha or Charlies Delta Charlie regarding adverse reactions. column3: Problem is that drones last about 25 to 30 minutes tops on one battery. This having to land to pick up data for something like the USDA soil survey::: would mean someone out there swapping batteries all day::: when they could easily drive around on a 4-wheeler like they do already and take samples by hand.  I do not think we should give up on the technology because it can get us in those hard to reach places but until batteries last longer and we have greater technology::: these are still only good for photographs due to their low weight bearing capacity. column42: Question for Virginia Tech's legal team: the University's legal basis for mandating vaccination is based solely on the Attorney General's 4/26/ 21 advisory opinion. There is no legislation or precedent::: just this OAG opinion. The opinion said a university "may condition in-person attendance on receipt of an approved COVID-19 vaccine during this time of pandemic." The last phrase::: "during this time of pandemic" is most important-\-\attaching the mandate to a public health emergency is what gave the AG a valid legal argument. But "during this time of pandemic" also needs to be clarified now: the Governor's state of emergency ended. The Commonwealth of Virginia is no longer in an emergency situation; therefore it follows we are no longer in "this time of pandemic"; therefore it follows the OAG opinion is no longer applicable; therefore it follows Virginia Tech no longer has any legal basis for mandating vaccinations. So how can the University still legally mandate vaccinations?

column26: Sarah Whillock
column27: Vaccine Information Open Letter from Physicians to Universities: Allow Students Back Without COVID Vaccine Mandate  Share:  Dear Deans::: Governing Boards and Trustees:::  On behalf of the Association of American Physicians and Surgeons::: I am writing to ask you to reconsider your new policy mandating COVID-19 vaccination of students prior to returning to campus.[i] Institutions of higher learning are divided on this issue.[ii] :::[iii] Although::: at first glance::: the policy may seem prudent::: it coerces students into bearing unneeded and unknown risk and is at heart contrary to the bedrock medical principle of informed consent.  There are multiple reasons to reverse your policy. I ask you to consider the following:  Young adults are a healthy and immunologically competent and vibrant group that is at::: ‚Äúextraordinary low risk for COVID-19 morbidity and mortality.‚Äù[iv] College and University students::: however::: are under significant mental health strain already from COVID-19 fears::: circumstances::: distance learning problems and the imposition of government health policy restrictions.[v ] Even though the FDA granted Emergency Use Authorization (EUA) for three COVID-19 vaccines::: they are not FDA approved to treat::: cure or prevent any disease at this time. Clinical trials will continue for at least two years before the FDA can even consider approval of these vaccines as effective and safe. The COVID-19 vaccines on the market in the U.S.::: mRNA (Moderna and Pfizer) and DNA (Johnson & Johnson ‚Äì Janssen)::: have caused notable side effects::: pathology and even death (4.178 deaths per VAERS as of May 5::: 2021). These adverse reactions result in absence from school and work::: hospital visits::: and even loss of life.[vi] College-age women may be at unique risk for adverse events following administration of the experimental COVID vaccinations currently available. According to the CDC::: all cases of life-threatenin g blood clots::: subsequent to receiving the J&J vaccine::: reported so far in the United States::: occurred in younger women.[vii] The vast majority of cases of anaphylaxis have also occurred in women.[viii] In addition::: ‚Äúwomen are reporting having irregular menstrual cycles after getting the coronavirus vaccine:::‚Äù[ix] and 95 miscarriages have been reported to the U.S. Vaccine Adverse Effects Reporting System (VAERS) following COVID vaccination as of April 24::: 2021.[x] Recent research data demonstrates that the spike protein::: present on the SARS-CoV-2 virus and the induced primary mechanism of action of COVID-19 vaccines::: are the primary cause of disease::: infirmity::: hospitalization and death.[xi] Students who have had self-limited cases of COVID-19 already possess antibodies::: activated B-cells::: activated T-cells (detectable by lab testing). This durable::: long-term immunity would not only prevent them from getting recurrent COVID-19::: but would also represent herd immunity to protect others in the college or university community.[xii] :::[xiii] COVID-19 convalescent students may be harmed by college and university policy requiring COVID-19 vaccines.[xiv] They already have extensive immunity and would be likely harmed from a forced confrontation with COVID-19 vaccine induced spike protein causing autoimmune reactions leading to illness and possible death.[xv] Students and their families may justifiably believe these policies discriminate against individuals who aren‚Äôt candidates for this vaccine::: have pre-existing conditions::: previous COVID-19 disease::: cite religious objections::: or are otherwise exercising their freewill choosing not to participate in this optional vaccine experiment. Refer to the Nuremberg code from WWII::: which requires individuals::: ‚Äúto be able to exercise free power of choice::: without the intervention of any element of force‚Ä¶.‚Äù[xvi] Institutional policies that permit faculty to choose or refuse vaccination::: but do not allow students the same options::: raise equal protection constitutional issues. The ADA::: Americans with Disabilities Act::: requires ‚Äúreasonable accommodations::: ‚Äù be provided based on an individual‚Äôs own unique health situation. This includes rejection of an experimental vaccine intervention which may exacerbate known health problems and thereby cause harm. Colleges and Universities should consider whether they might be liable for damages::: poor health outcomes::: and loss of life due to mandatory COVID-19 vaccination policies.[xvii] ‚ÄúPositive cases:::‚Äù as defined by laboratory testing alone::: may be false positive testing errors or asymptomatic infection that is not clinically proven to spread disease. Ambulatory outpatient early treatment for SARS-CoV-2 infection / COVID-19 has been demonstrated effective in adults.[xviii] Informed consent is the standard for all medical interventions. The FDA factsheet for the healthcare provider reads::: ‚ÄúThe recipient or their caregiver has the option to accept or refuse (Pfizer-BioNTec h) vaccine.‚Äù Please reverse your decision to mandate experimental COVID-19 vaccines before more students are harmed and make the vaccines rightfully optional. Both unvaccinated and vaccinated students should be permitted on campus. Thank you for your time and attention. We would appreciate hearing back from you as soon as possible and welcome further discussion with you and other leaders at your institution.  Sincerely:::  Paul M. Kempen::: M.D.::: Ph.D. ‚Äì AAPS President (2021)  References  [i] https:// www.nydailynews. com/ coronavirus/ ny-covid-vaccine -several-colleg es-required-202 10407-yyfysfahx zbvrcx6n2w63dcw ue-story.html  [ii] https:// apnews.com/ article/ us-colleges-divi ded-student-cor onavirus-vaccin ation-8c46ab65a fc4538cb060c320 ed94fc54  [iii] https:// newjersey.news12 .com/ rowan-stockton-u niversities-wil l-not-require-c ovid-19-vaccine -to-attend  [iv] https:// www.andrewbostom .org/2021/04/ audio-dr-andrew- bostom-with-wpr os-matt-allen-4 -5-21-discussin g-roger-william s-universitys-m andatory-fall-2 021-covid-19-va ccination-for-s tudents-absent- any-reference-t o-their-ext/  [v] https:// pubmed.ncbi.nlm. nih.gov/ 33667243/  [vi] https:// www.nydailynews. com/ coronavirus/ ny-covid-ohio-st udent-death-joh nson-shot-20210 416-hm54bbifnvg c7ggxxc4cxrvpui -story.html  [vii] https:// www.cdc.gov/ media/releases/ 2021/ fda-cdc-lift-vac cine-use.html  [viii] https:// jamanetwork.com/ journals/jama/ fullarticle/ 2776557  [ix] https:// www.ajc.com/ life/ women-reporting- irregular-menst rual-cycle-afte r-vaccination/ XRN2P4FOWRAV7DIP YTU2MO67VA/  [x] https:// wonder.cdc.gov/ vaers.html  [xi] https:// www.qeios.com/ read/26GTOD.2/ pdf  [xii] https:// www.nature.com/ articles/ s41577-020-00436 -4  [xiii] https:// www.nih.gov/ news-events/ nih-research-mat ters/ lasting-immunity -found-after-re covery-covid-19  [xiv] https:// www.aier.org/ article/ if-you-had-covid -do-you-need-th e-vaccine/  [xv] https:// noorchashm.mediu m.com/ uregnt-fda-commu nication-catast rophic-blood-cl ot-risk-absent- medical-necessi ty-of-covid-19- a6bb35b806df  [xvi] http:// www.cirp.org/ library/ethics/ nuremberg/  [xvii] https:// thehill.com/ regulation/ labor/ 541173-first-cas e-against-manda tory-vaccinatio n-filed-in-new- mexico-dention- center?rl=1

column73: In January::: Israel became one of the first countries in the world to give the new coronavirus vaccine to young people. At the time::: Israel's Education Ministry said the vaccine was necessary so that students could sit for in-person exams. Schools mandated the shot; kids got it.  So what happened next? This week::: we found out. Israeli health officials released a report showing that vaccinated young people::: particularly young men::: were developing a potentially fatal complication ‚Äî a heart inflammation called myocarditis ‚Äî and they were developing it at extremely high rates. Researchers determined that the incidence of myocarditis in vaccinated young men was fully 25 times the usual rate. Some of them died.  In Canada::: at least one public health official observed the same thing. Dr. Peter Liu is the chief scientific officer at the University of Ottawa Heart Institute::: and an expert in myocarditis. Liu began to notice heart inflammation in patients who‚Äôd received the vaccine. ‚ÄúIt is more than coincidental:::‚Äù he said. In Germany::: authorities concluded the same thing. The German government just announced that healthy young people should avoid the vaccine. It‚Äôs too dangerous.  This is a serious development. If statistical trends observed in Israel hold here in the United States::: as many as 150:::000 young Americans will develop a potentially fatal heart disorder because of this vaccine. That‚Äôs not alarmism::: or some kind of anti-vaccine conspiracy theory. It‚Äôs real. Has VT looked into this study prior to making this decision to mandate?

column90: This is why STAFF will not be MANDATED to vaccinate: OSHA released its new guidance on April 20 under a ‚ÄúFrequently Asked Questions‚Äù section of its website having to do with COVID-19 safety compliance.  The question asks whether an employer who mandates employees receive these experimental COVID-19 shots is required to record any adverse events as a result of these injections. Such recording requirements of serious work-related injuries and illness may not only leave an employer vulnerable to worker‚Äôs compensation claims::: but such incidents could also impact the employer‚Äôs safety record.  The question and answer in full:  If I require my employees to take the COVID-19 vaccine as a condition of their employment::: are adverse reactions to the vaccine recordable?  If you require your employees to be vaccinated as a condition of employment (i.e.::: for work-related reasons)::: then any adverse reaction to the COVID-19 vaccine is work-related. The adverse reaction is recordable if it is a new case under 29 CFR 1904.6 and meets one or more of the general recording criteria in 29 CFR 1904.7.  This clarification comes as an increasing number of employers seek to mandate the experimental injections despite possible illegality. The Wall Street Journal (WSJ) reported this beginning trend in varieties of fields::: including machine operators::: office workers::: restaurant waiters::: and medical staff.

Here's a common one: "The median wage for high-school-edu cated workers fell by 11.1% between 1979 and 2019." https:// fas.org/sgp/crs/ misc/R45090.pdf  For those 25 and over::: in 1979::: 32% had not finished high school::: and only 84% did not have a college education. column1: At Virginia Tech::: scientists are coming together with research::: technology::: and a sense of Ut Prosim to uncover opportunities for support::: recovery::: and awareness of substance misuse on campus::: at home::: and in the community.  They are conducting research to learn more about why people use substances::: working with community groups and public schools to evaluate the impact of positive interventions::: and using what they learn to advocate for better outcomes for both people who use and those impacted by using.  Breaking Through | Virginia Tech Magazine  Breaking Through | Virginia Tech Magazine  Breaking Through | Virginia Tech Magazine  Breaking Through | Virginia Tech Magazine  Breaking Through | Virginia Tech Magazine  See more at vtmag.vt.edu

A message from President Tim Sands::: VP Menah Pratt-Clarke::: and VP Frank Shushok Jr.:  "As we reflect on our motto::: Ut Prosim (That I May Serve)::: we have a profound responsibility to serve the world through an educational environment that opposes racist ideology and behaviors and builds a community that affirms the inherent dignity and value of every person. We have the opportunity to send graduates into the world who are passionately committed to dismantling racism::: hatred::: and exclusionary practices that have brought about incalculable suffering and death of Black and African Americans::: as well as other marginalized communities."  VTNEWS.VT.EDU A message from President Tim Sands::: Vice President Menah Pratt-Clarke::: and Vice President Frank Shushok Jr.

column9: I remember getting up to leave my System Dynamics class when we were abruptly stopped::: and students -\-\ students who had just witnessed their classmates killed-\-\ were evacuated into Norris hall right across the street into our room in Randolph. It was a surreal moment for everyone as the reality of what was happening slowly set in.  In the days and weeks that followed::: we all dealt with it in our own way::: but I want to echo some of the comments I saw on this post already: I will always be proud of how well my university and my Blacksburg community handled it all. Virginia Tech is an amazing place- more than just a great university for most of us...it's a second home.  As for the rest of our country::: these issues still persist to date. There is plenty that can and will be done to prevent these types of events in the future. The #1 thing we can all do::: starting right now::: is be kind to everyone you meet. Give the weird kid in class a genuine smile and tell them you're glad they are there. Pay for the person's lunch at the drive-thru and pass them a note to let them know they matter. Just talk to people that no one else talks to. Planting seeds of kindness now can help prevent events like April 16::: 2007 from happening in the future. It's not the only thing to be done::: but it is the easiest::: and you can do it now.

column1: Town of Blacksburg Government's Amended Emergency Ordinance 1956 does not apply to Virginia Tech operations and will not impact events such as commencement.  Town of Blacksburg Government March 24::: 2021 at 10:12 AM ¬∑  üîµ Amended Emergency Ordinance 1956 Clarification üîµ  Because some confusion has resulted from the Town Council‚Äôs action to approve Amended Emergency Ordinance 1956::: the Town is providing the following clarifications.  The Town's emergency ordinance does not apply to Virginia Tech operations and will not impact events such as graduation.  All of the measures in the emergency ordinance have been in place since first adopted by the Town Council in August of 2020 before the students returned to Blacksburg. The limit on gatherings (50 persons) remains in place due to Blacksburg‚Äôs unique circumstances as a college town and the prevalence of COVID-19 cases in the student population.  The Town‚Äôs emergency ordinance is consistent with the current Governor‚Äôs order except for the limit on large outdoor gatherings (a limit of 50 instead of the 100 persons permitted on April 1). This is to prevent large private gatherings/parties that could continue the spread of COVID-19 in the student population. This limitation does not apply to the operation of food establishments or businesses.  Town staff is directly coordinating with Virginia Tech to plan for successful in-person graduation ceremonies and will welcome graduating students and their families to Blacksburg in May.  More information will come out in the coming weeks as Virginia Tech announces plans for graduation week.

column3: This announcement shows a complete lack of innovation on the part of VT administration & is frankly infuriating. We expect the students to innovate and learn from good examples. I expect the same from VT administration::: who have lost my trust with this announcement.  Student only department ceremonies are possible NOW. Each department is small and each department traditionally does a ceremony. It is the department ceremony students remember long after graduation. Let the big ceremony in Lane be split or virtual & give the students department ceremonies with their peers. Use West Point or ANY of the other military academies as an example - all of which had ceremonies last spring. My younger daughter‚Äôs HIGH SCHOOL had an in-person::: student-only ceremony LAST SPRING::: with NO COVID cases after::: for 260 students - bigger than many VT departments. As a senior parent::: I will give up being there::: if my daughter can have a ceremony with peers & have the experience she‚Äôs earned.  This announcement is completely unacceptable. The students have lost too much already and VT has the obligation to do better. As an alumni parent::: I find the timing suspect - right after Giving Day???? At this point::: I have such bad feelings::: I don‚Äôt know how I can continue to talk up VT to the accepted HS seniors on my robotics team and I feel tricked by the ‚Äújust after‚Äù Giving Day timing. I am disgusted by the lack of effort on the part of VT - it‚Äôs time to step up and SERVE your students::: not subject them to this unbelievable DISSERVICE.

column1: Due to forecasted inclement weather conditions::: the Blacksburg Virginia Tech campus will be closed tomorrow::: Feb. 18.  All day and evening classes::: regardless of modality (in person::: hybrid or online) have been canceled. All university events scheduled are also canceled. ‚ùÑÔ∏è  For more information visit vt.edu/status.
column3: Oh brother. Most students have classes on line and we are expected to lose power and internet in the ice build up. It's not about walking in the snow üôÑ
column4: Hopefully the power will stay on. I remember living in West Egg during the blizzard of 93 (or was it 94) and the campus lost power and we were sent home early for Spring Break. And then we were delayed returning from Spring Break because of a snow storm. Good times. The campus was so beautiful when it snowed.
column5: Dear everyone saying they were at tech during the 60s-90s and never had classes canceled: 1. We are so much online that if the electricity goes out::: most classes wouldn't have students in them let alone professors. 2. Times are different and things change. If you want to argue that::: take that up with your God or higher power. Please don't let me know how it goes. 3. Students now are expected to be more and do more than you were so ease up on the judgment.
column6: Weak. I went there 10 years ago and the campus never closed due to weather from what I remember. Power and internet are pretty reliable in Blacksburg. Trudging through snow to class should stay part of the campus experience. Next you're going to tell me the Pritchard vs Cadet Corp snowball fight is no more.
column7: I was there from 2004-2008::: and as long as buses could run their routes::: the campus was open. Being in the Corps::: and doing Army ROTC::: we were up for PT long before they made any decisions about delays or campus closures::: and were outside at time in negative temperature wind chills. The Officer of the Day would dictate the uniform for morning formations based an automated telephonic report from Roanoke (which is always warmer than Blacksburg)::: so we‚Äôd be going to formation in much colder temperatures than the report stated.
column8: Back in my day we had to cross the Drill Field that had no paths::: in the slush and mud::: sometimes on our hands and knees squinting into blowing snow::: through the small stream that always developed from snow melt::: carrying our boxes of punch cards for programming class (had to dry them out on radiators when we got there)::: all the while fighting off starving wolves and cougars that came down from the hills in search of cafeteria scraps!
column9: Everyone is claiming VT never cancelled when they went there::: but I remember sitting in the TV lounge between East and West AJ in 1987 watching the Super Bowl and it being announced that classes were cancelled the following day.
column10: It was believable until the wildlife coming for cafeteria scraps- they would run the other direction
column11: I believe it was in 1974 or 75::: coming back from thanksgiving::: terrified driving across Afton mountain-total whiteout; back on campus::: classes were cancelled on Monday and there were the most amazing snowmen (and ‚Äúparts‚Äù of men!) and snow sculptures all over the drillfield. Great memories! Walking home from working at the library late during exams‚Äîpainfully cold.
column12: I'm not making this observation to draw anyone's derision::: but this is Facebook so we'll see what happens.  Many of the comments about classes not being cancelled in 19XX precede the ADA becoming law. There's a notable difference between how the University handled inclement weather when I was a student and how they have handled it since I became a member of the faculty. It's a net positive.
column13: We were there in 1958 and classes were not cancelled; we walked across the drill field with strong winds. It was unbearable::: but we did it!
column14: CLOSED?? Are you kidding? We had classes even when snow was waist high!! Back in those days a lot of where there are steps now::: we‚Äôre just paved over hills. We would have to take a running start to scramble up those hills that were nothing but a sheet of ice. We either made it::: or wiped out swooshing to the bottom and have to start all over again. And we did it in silence. We were bundled so tightly including our faces and mouths::: no one would have heard our cries for help anyway!
column15: I can remember classes being canceled once in the mid 80‚Äôs. This was because it was so cold that the infirmary (Henderson Hall) couldn‚Äôt handle all of the students who had frost bite. I also remember almost crawling across the Drill field during an icy January afternoon in 1982 trying to get to McBryde for a class only to discover class was canceled because the professor couldn‚Äôt get to campus. It was a LONG walk back to WAJ that day... ü•∂
column16: I remember going to class during Hurricane Hugo. They didn't decide to cancel class until after 8am. There were whole sections of forest blown over like matchsticks during that one. 1989
column17: We are class of 1984. My roommate and best friend Robin Nixon Meritt from 6th grade weighed about 98 pounds our sophomore year. In spring 2019::: Hokies in the VT Corps of Cadets started the Black Cadet Organization (BCO) as a way to bring Black cadets together. Today::: the BCO has grown into a group of cadets who celebrate Black culture and offer support to all cadets.  VTNEWS.VT.EDU Black Cadet Organization provides community for all cadets
column3: We ask our community to remember::: embrace::: and embody the Virginia Tech Principles of Community every day ‚Äî and especially during these times. This is a reminder that we reject all forms of prejudice and discrimination and we take individual and collective responsibility for helping to eliminate bias and discrimination. It is critical for Hokie nation to come together to create a culture of civility in our communities and across the country.  We remind our online community to abide by our commenting guidelines::: found in our page‚Äôs About section: https:// www.facebook.com /virginiatech/ about  Comments may be removed if they are off-topic::: defamatory::: an unauthorized commercial solicitation::: or an attack::: or if they contain illegal suggestions or use foul language. We reserve the right to terminate access to the page by repeat offenders.
column4: It's great to see that there are enough AfAm Cadets to form this community. I hope the community will grow. Sixteen percent of the military is Black. This is a great step. Don't be afraid of it. Celebrate it.
column5: What the point to join Cadets::: wear the same uniform::: shave our head as freshman::: and do all other same stuff....

column1: Because of the university‚Äôs ongoing commitment to limit the spread of COVID-19 and protect the members of our extended community::: Virginia Tech will alter its 2021 Day of Remembrance events to promote physical distancing and discourage large public gatherings. Flowers and wreaths will be placed at the memorial and individual memorial stones. All public gatherings traditionally held on that day will not take place.  On the Day of Remembrance::: members of our community are encouraged to pause and honor the 32 individuals who lost their lives on April 16::: 2007::: in a manner most meaningful to you. column4: TO VACCINATE OR NOT VACCINATE - that is the question....  AGREED! I'M NOT GETTING IT!!!  1. Can I stop wearing a mask? No::: now Fauci suggesting 2 mask  2. Can they reopen restaurants etc and everyone work normally? No  3. Will I be resistant to COVID? Maybe::: but they don‚Äôt know exactly. It probably won‚Äôt stop me getting it.  4. At least I won‚Äôt be contagious to others::: right? No::: I can still pass it on::: maybe...nobody knows.  5. If we vaccinate children::: will schools resume normally? No  6. If I‚Äôm vaccinated::: can I stop social distancing? No  7. If I‚Äôm vaccinated::: can I stop disinfecting my hands? No  8. If I vaccinate myself and my grandpa::: can we hug each other? No  9. Will movie theaters::: stadiums etc. be reopened thanks to vaccines? No  10. Will the vaccinated be able to gather? No  11. What‚Äôs the real benefit to vaccination? The virus won‚Äôt kill you.  12. Are you sure it won‚Äôt kill me? No  13. If statistically the virus doesn‚Äôt kill me anyway::: why would I get vaccinated? To protect others.  14. So if I get vaccinated::: is everyone sure that I‚Äôm not infecting them? No  15. So if I have a fatal reaction to the experimental vaccine will the manufacturer be held liable? No  So::: the vaccine doesn‚Äôt give immunity. Doesn‚Äôt eliminate the virus. Doesn‚Äôt prevent death. Doesn‚Äôt guarantee you won‚Äôt get COVID. Doesn‚Äôt prevent you from getting COVID. Doesn‚Äôt stop you from passing it on. Doesn‚Äôt eliminate the need for travel bans. Doesn‚Äôt eliminate the need for business closures. Doesn‚Äôt eliminate the need for lockdowns. Doesn‚Äôt eliminate the need for masks. Doesn't hold vaccine manufacturers liable  So...why should I take an experimental vaccine? Everyone has a choice and it‚Äôs your choice.

column1: The $10 million gift from Virginia Tech Alumni Mehul Sanghani ‚Äô98 and Hema Sanghani ‚Äô99 will help Virginia Tech lead in the development and application of the next generation of artificial intelligence and data science capabilities.  This support comes at the perfect time ‚Äî with the construction of the first #VTInnovationCampus academic building on track to start this year::: the Sanghani Center will attract talented new students and faculty who will shape the future of how humanity engages with AI and data analytics.

Our VT Molecular Diagnostics Laboratory at the Fralin Biomedical Research Institute has already processed more than 70:::000 COVID-19 tests for the university community and Virginia Department of Health districts across the Commonwealth and they're prepared for the return of our students.  With the capacity to process up to 5:::000 test samples per week::: the lab is ready to process hundreds of samples from students and employees over the next few weeks.  Since Virginia Tech was selected as one of the state‚Äôs three exclusive OneLab Network Tier 2 laboratories to help expand COVID-19 testing capacity across Virginia::: the lab will also continue to analyze tests collected by VDH that come from community testing events::: businesses::: schools::: and assisted living facilities across Virginia.  Please remember that students are asked to quarantine for 10 days prior to returning to campus; you can learn more about Virginia Tech testing at ready.vt.edu/testing. With deep gratitude::: President Sands thanks Hokies for the outstanding work across all of our campuses this year.  Thank you to the Fralin Biomedical Research Institute and Schiffert Health Center for their work on COVID-19 testing; Linsey Marr for sharing her expertise on airborne virus transmission; the employees who kept our classrooms open and our community safe; the students who adapted to changes and protected others; the Town of Blacksburg Government and community partners who offered support::: and many::: many more ‚Äî we appreciate you. üß°  Despite extraordinary challenges::: you remained committed to Ut Prosim and we are so grateful for this community that truly cares for one another.  While we will continue to face COVID-19 challenges in the coming months::: we have established a framework and demonstrated the resilience necessary to succeed.  Enjoy your break! column1: In 1953::: Virginia Tech accepted one Black student. In 2020::: Virginia Tech welcomed 571 Black students. As the first Black student admitted to Virginia Tech::: Peddrew will recount his journey and experience at the university.  VTNEWS.VT.EDU Irving Peddrew discusses his experience as Virginia Tech's first Black student
column3: I‚Äôm not sure why people on this thread seem to think VT is satisfied with the current enrollment number of 571 Black students. It is an indicator of progress::: not goal attainment. VT has placed an emphasis::: as it should::: on increasing minority enrollment and continues to do so.

column9: Most of these comments are cringe. No nuance at all. Completely throwing merit::: academic preparedness::: and application numbers out the window. column16: Where a person chooses to attend college is just that a personal choice. My daughter had her heart set on NC State::: until she saw the cost. She loves VT and the program she is in.
column17: For those that like to throw numbers around (and I'm a VT engineering alumnus)::: what would be a "good" number? Why is 571 "not good enough"? Is it supposed to equal the state's ratio? Is it supposed to equal the nation's ratio? Is it supposed to equal the local ratio? Do you know how many blacks applied? How many were denied? Do you know how many total students applied? How many were denied?  Kinda hard to draw a conclusion on a single data point. What if a large % were internationals? Indians? Chinese? Would you say that's diverse? What if it's a significant increase from previous years even relative to the number of applicants? Would that suffice? What if the number of black applicants were low but the % admitted was higher? Would that be good enough?  So before yall just start throwing shade on a pretty kickass university's page::: do us all alumni a favor and stop making us look like idiots. Stop trying to draw conclusions on a lab you slept through because you partied too hard from a Thursday night game üòÅ

column19: I'm a little disappointed by alot of these comments from fellow Hokies. While 571 may not be high enough in your mind::: you have to remember there is still an admissions process. Secondly::: you still have to meet the school requirements for admission::: GPA::: SAT::: and overall resume from high school. Thirdly::: VT is not for everyone. It's not in:::a city setting and maybe that will turn people away. Personally::: I think VT has one of the best campuses in the nation. So while 571 is good::: I'm sure it will keep getting better.

Previous mask efficacy studies have focused on masks used by healthcare workers::: like N95 respirators::: but what about the cloth face coverings that many are purchasing and making at home?  Virginia Tech expert in airborne disease transmission::: Linsey Marr::: and her Virginia Tech Civil & Environmental Engineering team set out to answer this question through a new study examining the efficacy of common face coverings.  Marr and her team tested nine different homemade masks for their ability to trap particles to help protect both mask wearers and those nearby::: with a focus on particle sizes common to breathing and speaking. ‚¨áÔ∏è  VTNEWS.VT.EDU Study shows cloth face coverings help protect both wearers and those nearby

column39: Interesting study. Testing under ideal controlled circumstances is useful knowledge::: however::: it leaves out a whole lot of human behavior and mask design/ fit issues. I work in a museum that has been open to the public since July and we have not had::: thank goodness::: a traceable outbreak related to our venue. We are not using all of our facilities::: mostly outside portion::: but we do have some head count control attendance for a large indoor exhibit area where social distancing is possible. When it comes to mask wearing....I've seen it all and believe me there's not a lot of 'ideal controlled circumstances' going on anywhere. If the constant handling and adjusting I've seen is any indication then masks are virtually worthless due to human behavior::: poor fit::: and sloppy wearing. I'm not talking about anyone being defiant or rude::: just people in general touch::: move::: remove::: and replace the masks every couple of minutes. People take them off::: wave them around::: dangle them around their wrists::: stuff them in their pockets::: then pull them back out::: put them on and start the entire cycle all over again. It's both hilarious and frightening. Please don't think that just because you see someone wearing a mask that they aren't still able to pass the virus.
column40: Use common sense. Any mask is better than no mask. Just wear one for the greater common good. If you don‚Äôt have risk factors try to think of the others you come in contact with that might. It‚Äôs not about your freedom it‚Äôs about trying to mitigate the risk for everyone.
column41: For the one who asked me what percentage do I think masks work (your comment was deleted for some reason and I don't remember your name) here is my answer: From what I have seen::: N95 masks are 95% effective::: surgical masks are 60% effective::: this medical journal article places face coverings at 65%. I would even take 10% if it meant a chance to protect my father and my family and those I love. I do research science and medical articles concerning the effectiveness. Of course they need to be combined with hand washing/ Sanitizing::: distancing (which can be impossible when anti-maskers don't think they have to distance::: wash their hands::: clean cart handles::: etc. in stores. https:// www.thelancet.co m/journals/ lancet/article/ PIIS0140-6736(20 )31142-9/ fulltext
column42: I want to know how many people actually sneeze in a mask that they have to wear all day? I might clear my throat in my mask::: but if I have to sneeze my mask comes down and I get a tissue to sneeze. Seems extremely gross to sneeze in a mask.
column43: Late to the game but It's a nice study and a very good effort but as the author stated::: it's a lab study. column1: With indoor studio space limited due to COVID-19::: faculty are getting creative with ways to maximize face-to-face opportunities for students in safe and impactful ways. Virginia Tech's dedicated air quality team has been working to enhance the health and safety of university physical spaces since before the pandemic began. This team and our robust air quality program continues to provide a strong foundation for initiatives underway that help reduce airborne transmission of COVID-19. üí®  Throughout the pandemic::: team members have implemented a stringent air filter replacement operation and examined nearly every major piece of HVAC equipment on the Blacksburg campus. They are also continuing to make adjustments as needed around air ventilation rates::: system flushing::: and bringing outdoor air inside to maximize ventilation.

Read about the recent BOV meeting::: where we discussed the next iteration of the Climate Action Commitment to guide Virginia Tech toward a more sustainable future::: presented a design for the Corps Leadership and Military Science Building::: and reviewed the impact of COVID-19 on campus programs and operations. ‚¨áÔ∏è  VTNEWS.VT.EDU Impact of COVID-19 pandemic continues to inform Board of Visitors meetings

column1: In response to the widespread use of tear gas to disperse pro-democracy protesters in Hong Kong::: Virginia Tech School of Architecture + Design students created the T.E.A.R. Mask.  The T.E.A.R. mask is a pocket-sized anti-tear gas respirator that protects the eyes::: nose::: and mouth from the harmful effects of tear gas.  Not only does this project bring attention to the misuse of tear gas and represent the importance of human rights::: but it was also recognized by the Industrial Designers Society of America - IDSA with a coveted 2020 Industrial Design Excellence Award. üèÜ  VTNEWS.VT.EDU Student-designed tear gas safety mask wins top industrial design award

Virginia Tech will start and finish the 2021 spring semester as originally planned::: with a modified spring break to discourage travel that may increase the risk of contracting or transmitting COVID-19.  ‚û°Ô∏è Classes will begin on Jan. 19 and all instruction will be delivered fully online through Jan. 22. Virginia Tech Dining Services centers will open for residential students on Jan. 16 at noon.  ‚û°Ô∏è ‚Äúspring break‚Äù will consist of five one-day breaks in which classes will not be held. These one-day breaks will have no classes::: assignments::: nor assessments and will take place on Feb. 5::: Feb. 25::: March 17::: April 6::: and April 26.  ‚û°Ô∏è Classes will end on May 5 and final exams will be held May 7-12. The hatred in some of these comments is not in line with the values we're meant to embody as Hokies (also::: considering we're one of the best STEM schools in Virginia::: you'd think some people would have more respect for the science that clearly shows that COVID-19 is a threat::: even to people in our age group). As a student::: I don't see why we can't acknowledge that this is a stress-inducing and inefficient solution while also acknowledging that holding spring break as normal may not have been the best idea during a pandemic when I firsthand have seen countless students refusing to follow COVID-19 guidelines set by the university. I know we're all upset about Tech handing us an option that only adds to our stress::: but that doesn't mean we should suddenly pretend the pandemic was going to be over by March and act like our fellow Hokies haven't been breaking the rules. Personally think that Tech could have mitigated this by having harsher consequences for those who have been acting carelessly::: but I guess it's too late for that now...

column68: In most responses the University has taken to COVID::: the friendly::: happy::: Hokie Spirit and traditions that make Va Tech feel like HOME and inspire lifelong alumni loyalty have been diminished. Va Tech is running out of time with the current students and needs to be way MORE CREATIVE in their response to COVID. Our best loved traditions not only inspire loyalty::: but allow the hard working students to blow off steam::: stimulating emotional balance and mental well being.  I am a VT alumni with two daughters at two different ACC schools::: Va Tech and Ga Tech. My GT daughter JUMPED for joy when she won the lottery to attend a football game and got to yell::: cheer and blow off steam at the game. The euphoria lasted over a week and provided a much needed emotional recharge. Va Tech should put the maximum number of students allowed in the stadium. Push back on the state government to increase that maximum::: because the stadium can easily hold more than 1000 safely distanced and they should think outside the box to include more students in the fan experience. How about a giant screen::: the cheer leaders and 1000 more students in the baseball stadium? Get them JUMPING::: cheering and yelling LET‚ÄôS GO HOKIES!! So loud everyone in Lane can hear them! A school whose fans are measured on the Richter Scale can surely do better than silent paper cut outs.  While I understand the need to keep the Va Tech and Blacksburg Community safe::: Spring Break provides hard working students with a necessary emotional and mental outlet and recharge::: allowing them to push through the rest of the semester. ‚ÄúWork Hard/Play Hard‚Äù is a phrase because humans need balance. If the university goes forward with the 5 single day off plan::: they need to do a better job of providing for the emotional well being of students who are starting to view HOKIE STONE in terms of PRISON GRAY.  These days must be free from school work::: by making an unbreakable::: ‚Äúnothing due the next class‚Äù rule::: and they must replace the physical::: emotional::: fun aspects a real spring break would have provided. Some ideas are: distanced drill field & lane stadium games where friend pods can compete against other pods to win prizes::: bussed outings to the cascades & other bucket list trails::: floats down the new river::: many small group service events::: and other bucket list items. It doesn‚Äôt have to fancy::: but it does have to be fun::: outside and spirit building. At Ga Tech they did their annual cake race in staggered heats::: Va Tech could do the 3.2 the same way allowing the event to continue. The Big Event could be split across several weekends allowing negative testing Hokies to help the surrounding community. Surely::: our outstanding corps of cadets who are experts in both leadership and logistics could help make these plans work?  Look at every traditional Va Tech event and find a safe way to implement and then look at all the experience/ well being factors of spring break and add those elements to the days off. Anything less::: will be a failure to live up to our ‚ÄúUt Prosim‚Äù motto::: because in this case the University must find better ways to serve the students::: who came to the amazing place that is Va Tech to learn and grow through these traditions and experiences.
column69: I'm sorry how do you think this is better for ANYONE? No spring break for students to decompress and any employees you have with kids who DO have a real spring break will need to look into child care. Tech you are seriously messing up this year. column1: Food insecurity exists on college campuses nationwide and Virginia Tech is no exception. Their generosity supports "The Market of Virginia Tech:::" a new initiative that combats food insecurity by providing Hokies with enough fresh ingredients for seven days of meals so they can focus on their academic success. column1: ICYMI: A Virginia Tech Alumni couple::: Hema & Mehul Sanghani::: have stepped forward with a $1.5 million gift in support of "The Market of Virginia Tech:::" an initiative that combats food insecurity by helping Hokies get healthy meals so they can focus on their academic success. üëè  Want to help fuel student success and provide Hokies with healthy meals? Support The Market of Virginia Tech ‚û°Ô∏è bit.ly/marketofvt

When a Virginia Tech Alumni couple::: Hema and Mehul Sanghani::: learned how many #VirginiaTech students face food insecurity::: they felt compelled to act so that Hokies wouldn‚Äôt have to worry about how to get healthy meals.  The Sanghanis stepped forward in the spirit of #UtProsim with a $1.5 million donation that will enhance food-access at the university::: supporting the launch of an innovative program::: called The Market of Virginia Tech. Each week this initiative provides up to 75 students with enough fresh ingredients for seven days of meals::: helping to put Hokies on a path toward success. The Market differs from hundreds of university programs nationwide in that it‚Äôs an online-driven system ‚Äì providing more flexibility during the COVID-19 pandemic::: but also helping to maintain student privacy.  Thank you::: Hema and Mehul::: for your generosity and service that will allow Hokies to reach their full potential! üß°  VTNEWS.VT.EDU The Market of Virginia Tech helps provide healthy food to students in need

column1: Virginia Tech researchers have provided the first experimental evidence from a living organism to show that an abundant::: star-shaped brain cell known as an astrocyte is essential for blood-brain barrier health.  This finding will help scientists understand and develop effective treatments for diseases where frequent blood-brain barrier damage occurs::: including traumatic brain injury::: stroke::: epilepsy::: Alzheimer‚Äôs disease::: and Parkinson‚Äôs disease. üß†  VTNEWS.VT.EDU Scientists advance understanding of blood-brain barrier health with implications for brain disease  Fralin Biomedical Research Institute September 21::: 2020 at 9:25 AM ¬∑  New research led by assistant professor Stefanie Robel::: Ph.D.::: was published today in GLIA confirms that astrocytes support the blood-brain barrier!

column1: ‚ÄúAs soon as people hear ‚Äòairborne virus:::‚Äô there‚Äôs a tendency to panic. I knew it was important to get the right information out there. We do know how this moves and there are things we can do to reduce transmission.‚Äù  Dr. Linsey Marr::: one of only a few U.S. experts on the aerosol transmission of viruses::: shared her expertise with us yesterday to help the #VirginiaTech community better understand SARS-CoV-2 and how the virus moves through the air.  Read her COVID-19 tips below. ‚¨áÔ∏è  VTNEWS.VT.EDU Linsey Marr shares airborne virus knowledge::: COVID-19 tips during virtual conversation
column3: Remember the three Cs and the M:  ‚û°Ô∏è Avoid Close contact situations. Maintain distance from other people. Six feet doesn‚Äôt mark a magic barrier::: but the particles do dilute with distance. ‚û°Ô∏è Avoid Crowds. Being in large crowds increase the chances that one will be around someone infected with the virus::: and that the virus will spread to others. ‚û°Ô∏è Avoid Closed::: poorly ventilated spaces. Imagine a cigarette smoker. In this room::: will I take in any smoke? ‚û°Ô∏è Wear Masks.

column1: Join us in remembering Sept. 11::: 2001 and thanking the brave first responders. üß° üá∫üá∏  üì∏: Jackson Sirbaugh
column3: On this day::: 19 years ago::: I was only two weeks into my junior year of college as a new transfer student::: having just moved 600 miles away from my home in New York for the first time in my life. I was pulled from a classroom at Virginia Tech by a friend who notified me what was happening. Shattered::: frightened and helplessly far away::: I spent the entire day crying in the arms of people that barely knew me::: but embraced me as if I had been their family all my life. Virginia Tech was that community::: and they have remained family ever since.  I will never forget. ‚ù§Ô∏è

column3: Great! I'd love to ask him why housing supervisors on Oak Lane are "not legally allowed" to share that someone in a sorority house has tested positive for COVID-19 when that can easily be done anonymously::: as proven by the way that various apartment complexes like Hunters Ridge and Chasewood Downs have been handling their COVID-19 cases. If student safety is the priority::: why are supervisors only allowed to share that someone has tested positive if that person says they're comfortable with that information being shared? To clarify::: this isn't about sending out an email saying exactly who tested positive -\-\ it's just sending out a notification in general. Can't believe that not sending out a notification is even an option. How many students are we going to put at risk with this?

column18: Glad to see they are continuing to work on things that can help counteract the tendency of young people to believe it can't happen to them and find additional ways to keep tabs on things.  Had a serious almost "in your face" converstion with my junior at UMD this week about just what is and is not "doing your part" to keep the community safe. I focused a lot on what it will mean to people in the local community and as kids are sent home (taking their germs with them) if the school closes down before Thanksgiving. I hoped that framing it that way might help since guilt and concern for others seems to motivate that age group more that worry over self.  I saw the article in the Roanoke paper about how VT is moving some students to make more room for isolation space. While I empathize with the student who shared her disappointment::: I will not jump on the bandwagon of "THEY should have planned for more." The students (who like to tell us they are "adults" now and should be treated as such) have a responsibility here to do their part to limit the spread.  The more the students can be persuaded to take it seriously::: the better the plan will work and the more likely it will be that there can be some semblance of "normal college life" sooner rather than later. At least that is what I am hoping for my Hokie freshman. I hate that his first semester is unfolding this way.  Stepping off soapbox now. Thanks for listening :-)

column5: If a student‚Äôs classes have been moved online::: officially or otherwise::: can the student be allowed to go home (not move out::: just go home) for a few weeks or::: perhaps longer::: without fear of losing their housing contract??? If they have in-person classes in the spring semester::: the room they are paying for should be waiting for them! A student should have the right to do what they feel they need to do to keep safe! Protecting oneself should not have a punitive outcome. Losing their contract by going home for two weeks may have been a VT rule before the pandemic::: but why on earth would you enforce that now?!? And::: perhaps::: if they go home::: they should stay home this semester-\-\but give them that choice::: without worrying about housing insecurity next semester. A student::: along with their family::: should be able to make that decision without fear or worry that they won‚Äôt have a room next semester! Come on now!!! Please change your stance on this issue during this very difficult and stressful time! Why wouldn‚Äôt you??? Not asking for a refund::: just the freedom to make a personal decision about one‚Äôs own safety::: without added unnecessary worry or obstacles! Treat them like family (your Hokie family::: remember?) and leave the light on!

VT community total is significantly higher than 157 with a complete scope of all data.  Additionally::: VT required on and off campus students to return to the VT community::: has taken payment and is responsible for having known of possible unsafe actions of young adults. column20: As a parent of both a VT student and an Auburn student::: I would like to share this letter. Both of our children practiced social distancing::: did not attend parties and made good decisions. BOTH contracted COVID::: had mild symptoms and are now fine physically. They also now have immunity::: but they are struggling with the emotional toll the restrictions have taken. Please consider this letter from an Auburn parent...it is exceptionally well written!  My letter to Dr. Gogue. Copied to department heads::: student services and Governor Ivey.  _______________ _______________ _______________ _______________ _________  Please consider this a letter of sincere support and of strong suggestion.  I write this as a veteran teacher and a parent of a Senior at AU.  First::: I commend you for getting students and staff back on campus; this was not an easy feat::: and it was a bold decision in a time when public pressure didn‚Äôt welcome such courage. Second::: I encourage you to be forward thinking yet again and fully open campus::: including requiring professors (not in the high-risk subset) to teach in person. Our students need it::: and they deserve it. They had the courage to trust you::: take a leap of faith and come back to campus in light of a fearful public and skeptical government. Moreover::: they have been brave while facing this virus: spreading it (naturally)::: recovering from it::: remaining healthy after it::: and helping build immunity within the Auburn area. Our students should be valued::: applauded::: and celebrated- never targeted::: chastised::: or ostracized by the community they love. If the latter happens::: we will lose great students and families::: especially our Freshman.  The reality is that we knew positive cases would rise on campus given the students‚Äô collective travel and presence. We knew the students could catch the virus anywhere from anyone. We knew masks and social distancing were a precaution not a protection. And::: we all know that everyone (in an open society) will eventually get this virus like they get the flu: masks or no masks::: vaccine or no vaccine. I have had it and so will you. Our best advice to ourselves and to our students is to be realistic and positive::: take reasonable precautions::: and practice good overall health.  As I read posts from professors::: students and parents::: it‚Äôs disheartening to hear of the isolation::: division and disappointment alongside the more positive tales. Many educators and students (including our son) are making the best out of a difficult situation::: but most students are struggling. This current learning environment is not sustainable::: and it is not healthy::: because a meaningful life and education is rooted in social interaction and academic learning. Our commitment to educating the whole person needs to deepen now::: and our advocacy for our students needs to increase. Given recent advanced research::: the stability of our hospitals::: and the CDC revisions::: we must reevaluate our society‚Äôs response starting with our colleges and universities! Auburn University can continue its leadership in thought and action::: and they can be embolden by the following facts. One of our sons is back to classes-in person-at a college in Boston. Our daughter is back to in-person learning in high school. Our elementary & middle schools are open. Stores and restaurants are filled. Flights are packed. Our students are working on job sites. Folks are going back to their offices. Mask mandates are being lifted and so on. Let‚Äôs support our college students by offering the full college experience::: while we also learn from their battle with Covid-19 via studying their plasma and antibodies (voluntarily) in order to help the most vulnerable. We have a great opportunity to make a difference in the lives of our students and get our society back to normal with good health in mind.  Here is an editorial written by professors at my husband‚Äôs Alma mater::: the University of Notre Dame. They are advocating for their students to stay on campus and learn in person! Please read. I shared it on four AU/AL parent FB pages.  [https:// ndsmcobserver.co m/2020/08/ recalculating-th e-risks/](https:// ndsmcobserver.co m/2020/08/ recalculating-th e-risks/ ?fbclid=IwAR17-Z U8s85Rab6JCe4LR mS0kS4a2rypy8_J NL8rZfTkQxsdneM XqlNUuZ8)  Since government restrictions are of consequence::: I also called Governor Ivey and copied her. Perhaps our Alumni Associations can also implore our elected officials to support our universities and students more. We are in this together::: and we can do better together. War Eagle!  Respectfully:::  Marisa Novak::: M.Ed.  TN

column19: Virginia Tech *needs* to invest in increasing its testing capacity asap. 1:::000 tests a week is a recipe for disaster. At that rate::: Virginia Tech wouldn't finish testing its entire undergraduate student body by the end of the semester::: and as we know::: testing only provides a snapshot of the health for an individual. Just because a student::: faculty::: or staff member was healthy last week and wasn't spreading the virus::: doesn't mean that they are healthy this week and not spreading the virus. Without identifying and isolating such cases of asymptomatic spread::: I am skeptical about the long-term sustainability of Virginia Tech's opening. More testing IS possible. The University of Illinois Urbana-Champaig ne tested 10:::000 students/ faculty/staff in ONE day last week (1% of all testing nationwide!)::: but the administration would need to identify this as a priority and invest accordingly.  Additionally::: I would like to see more transparency from Virginia Tech about what levels of spread they will accept before taking certain actions like a two week shutdown (see Notre Dame) or a full move to online classes (see UNC). This way::: students and parents know what to expect if spread hits certain levels::: and town members wouldn't have the feeling of::: 'How long are they going to push this for.' This information should be published via VT News and social media as well as incorporated into the dashboard.

A reminder to faculty::: staff::: wage employees::: and every #VirginiaTech community member that we must all adhere to the same standards required of our students in order to limit the spread of #COVID19 and accomplish our fall semester goals.  Employee expectations:  ‚û°Ô∏è No unapproved::: work-related gathering involving more than 15 people is permitted. When a task cannot be accomplished without more than 15 people gathering::: a plan must be developed to mitigate health safety risk and be approved by the unit leader.  ‚û°Ô∏è Face masks/coverings are to be worn at all times when on campus. Exceptions include circumstances when an employee is working alone in a workspace with a closed door and if an employee is continually distanced from anyone else outdoors::: such as when exercising outdoors. However::: even under these outdoor conditions::: wearing a face covering will set a good example to the community at large. Exceptions and expectations relating to chronic health conditions are still applicable. For accommodations::: reach out to the Office of Equity and Accessibility.  VTNEWS.VT.EDU To all employees: Do your part to limit the spread of COVID-19

column1: A message from Frank Shushok Jr.::: VP for Virginia Tech Student Affairs:  "While developmental and collaborative approaches are the norm at Virginia Tech::: it is now clear that this public health crisis will not be solved without clear and definitive boundaries that are enforced with swift and serious action. The following requirements are to provide clarity in your decision-making:  üö® There should not be ANY non-university sanctioned/monitored gatherings::: on or off campus::: larger than 15 people.  üö® Face masks/coverings should be worn at all social gatherings::: with 6-foot physical distancing. Individuals should remove themselves from situations where this is not possible.  üö® Independent outdoor exercise is the only exception to the obligation of the face covering requirement.  To be clear::: failure to follow these expectations is considered endangering the welfare of others and will result in immediate interim suspension and removal from campus housing. Immediate interim suspension means no academic classes or student activities until a full student conduct hearing is complete. This will adversely impact your academic career.  Our student conduct program is typically designed with opportunities built in to learn from one‚Äôs mistakes. Yet these aren‚Äôt typical times. The nature of the pandemic means the health and well-being of our community must be the values that win the day. Therefore::: Virginia Tech will take swift action for all violations::: and the academic career of all involved will be impacted.  I am counting on ALL of us. Let‚Äôs get this right. Now."

The semester begins on Monday and we're looking forward to a great fall in Hokie nation. This is not what we expected::: but if we all do our part and remain committed to public health::: then we can stay together::: protect our community::: and have an amazing semester. ü¶É  ‚û°Ô∏è ready.vt.edu/well

column1: We are pleased to announce that the BOV voted unanimously this afternoon to rename two of our campus residence halls after African Americans who inspired the Hokie community and played an important role in shaping Virginia Tech.  The residence hall formerly known as Lee Hall will be named after the late William and Janie Hoge::: a local African American couple who played a critical role in the success and well-being of the first African American students attending Virginia Polytechnic Institute in the 1950s.  The residence hall formerly known as Barringer Hall will be named after James Leslie Whitehurst Jr. ‚Äô63::: the first Black student permitted to live on campus in 1961 and a U.S. Air Force veteran.  VTNEWS.VT.EDU Board of Visitors Executive Committee approves new names for residence halls

column126: I did some research on Barringer::: and found out he was our sixth president::: and a physician who wrote on eugenics. So this would make sense to change the name. He made major contributions to the university. I know the yearbook called him the father of terror::: however::: the university investigated this as far back as 1997 I believe::: and found no actual evidence of what he‚Äôs accused of::: and that it was more likely a distasteful joke amongst his classmates.  Despite this::: Tech has been very progressive since it‚Äôs opening- it allowed women to attend at the turn of the century::: was one of the first military schools to allow women in its Corps of Cadets::: and the first major public university in the South to voluntarily integrate::: which is incredible and awesome considering other states were mobilizing the National Guard to prevent African American students from integrating. column1: UPDATE (8/13/20 at 6:18 p.m.): The implementation of any new Cook Counseling fees has been canceled. Read more here: facebook.com/virginiatech/posts/10158762049498054  Cook Counseling Center has a two-fold commitment: to both maintain the current level of care for students and simultaneously manage the escalating costs for all students. In order to respond to current fiscal conditions::: not reduce the number of clinicians::: and not further increase the Health Services Fee::: Cook will be implementing a new fee structure for some services::: effective August 17.  It is important that Cook continue to see as many students as possible and these fees will allow them to do so while impacting as few students as possible. Students with demonstrable financial need can apply for fee waivers and these waivers will be reviewed on a case-by-case basis.  More information here: https://vtnews.vt.edu/notices/cook-counseling-fees-aug2020.html  VTNEWS.VT.EDU Update on Cook Counseling fee structure  Virginia Tech August 13::: 2020 at 5:13 PM ¬∑
