column52: This is extremely disappointing. I utilized Cook throughout my undergrad and it was so helpful. I‚Äôm sad to see that many students will now not have the opportunity to grow in counseling. Coming off of a 5+ month quarantine::: away from friends and social supports::: seems like a terrible time to add another barrier to seeking mental health services. When I worked as an RA::: I referred a countless number of my residents to Cook Counseling. I worry what extra burden this choice to limit health care access places on residence hall student staff::: the office of the dean of students::: etc. I know many of my residents and friends either could not have paid a fee::: or could not have had that line item on their bill for family to see. Unfortunately::: there is still a negative stigma against seeking mental health services. How will Cook plan to protect the privacy of their students? Hopefully in the future::: these funds could be raised in other ways to reduce the load for students.
column53: What about the students who rely on psychiatric services who are already struggling to afford their medication. $15 per session may seem like nothing to some but that‚Äôs the difference of being able to afford medication or not to others. With the rising rates of depression and anxiety this could quite literally become a situation of life or death::: but sure Tim Sands deserves a $200:::000 raise this year.
column54: Y‚Äôall still get TEN FREE appointments. And then after it‚Äôs only $20. Way better than community prices and way better than most other universities. Sadly the need is just so great that free counseling is just not feasible at most places anymore.
column55: Come on VT::: you can do better than this. Put your money where your mouth is! Mental wellness is of utmost importance and as an alum who has benefitted from cook counseling services and went on to finish my Master's in marriage and family therapy::: I know I wouldn't have been able to afford this fee. While the data you shared is accurate (which you do not cite in the statement)::: mental healthcare is fluid and different for each individual. Counselors deserve their funding and students deserve comprehensive care. I am very disappointed in this change and lack of awareness for how it will affect students. Please consult your Psychology and HDFS faculty about this for further information on how to do better than this. Imagine you connect with a counselor and shared very vulnerable parts of your life with them and built a trusting relationship for them to come back and say::: "oh::: by the way::: you are on your 11th session so you need to pay $20/visit now." And having to discontinue services and potentially regress in your symptoms because you can't access your counselor. That's a breeding ground for a whole new issue of ambiguous loss. Obviously the point of counseling is so that a patient/client can be better without the help of a counselor but for some that requires preparation to terminate on THEIR schedule. Some individuals struggle with attachment issues... Only clients and their counselors know when they are ready to terminate.
column56: The fee only goes into effect after the 10 ‚Äúfree‚Äù sessions. Everyone wishes unlimited services could be free::: but this is an incredibly reasonable solution

column1: Virginia Tech‚Äôs fall 2020 testing::: tracing::: and case management plan has been expanded with more information on how the university is enhancing testing protocols for students. column3: Students are encouraged to be tested before traveling to Town of Blacksburg Government::: so that students and their families have an opportunity to evaluate their plans and make adjustments if a positive result is returned. Students should submit their test results to the Schiffert Health Center as part of their health records.
column4: Prior to returning to Town of Blacksburg Government::: all students are expected to self-quarantine for 14 days::: wear face coverings when with others and follow all public health guidelines. Anyone who is traveling and is at-risk should self-quarantine and be tested if they develop COVID-19 symptoms.
column5: Testing is not required for students living off campus::: but it is required for at-risk off-campus students. These students should contact Schiffert Health Center to determine whether they should be tested.
column6: Testing through Schiffert Health Center during move-in (from Aug. 14-23) is required for on-campus students even if they have secured a negative polymerase chain reaction (PCR) COVID-19 test result prior to traveling to Town of Blacksburg Government.
column7: On-campus students who test positive for the virus::: or who have been potentially exposed to COVID-19 as determined by health care professionals::: will be asked to return to their permanent address and quarantine for 14 days. Students who cannot do so should contact the Dean of Students Office.
column8: Results of tests conducted by Schiffert Health Center should be available within 48 hours. All students who are tested are expected to self-quarantine until results are returned.
column9: Fralin Biomedical Research Institute's testing lab will be able to scale and meet the COVID-19 testing needs for Hokies::: allowing for a rapid return of results as the pace of testing quickens at the beginning of the semester. column1: See below for updates on Blacksburg Transit's plan for the fall and health measures being implemented. More to come::: but it is expected that ridership demand can be reasonably and safely accommodated.  üöç On 8/9::: BT will implement new passenger limits ‚Äî set at approximately two-thirds of capacity for large buses (an articulated bus will have a limit of 75 passengers and a regular-sized bus will have a limit of 45-55). üöç Passengers and drivers will be required to wear masks. üöç Thorough cleaning and disinfecting of buses. üöç Even though there will not be six feet of physical distancing at all times::: BT's average trip length is 10 minutes. (According to the CDC::: transmission is unlikely in brief interactions of less than 15 minutes::: even in close proximity.) üöç Barriers will be installed to provide a separation between the driver and passengers. üöç They will add an additional route on South Main St. and extend service on the CRC route. They will also provide fill-in buses to assist when there are full buses.  Blacksburg Transit July 23::: 2020 at 8:49 AM ¬∑  In preparation for the start of the fall semester::: BT will implement adjusted passenger limits effective Sunday::: August 9. These new limits will be set at approximately 2/3 capacity for large buses and 1/3 capacity for smaller buses.  These measures have been reviewed by the New River Health Department and are subject to change based on the rate of COVID-19 cases locally::: Governor‚Äôs Executive Orders::: or decisions by Virginia Tech that affect the demand for public transportation.  Full information is available at ridebt.org/fall2020

Virginia Tech is doing the best they can during this difficult time.  I applaud all they have done. Fingers crossed Spring semester looks more ‚Äúnormal‚Äù.

Virginia Tech has developed a fall 2020 comprehensive testing::: tracing::: and case management plan in coordination with Schiffert Health Center and the Virginia Department of Health to mitigate the spread of COVID-19. This plan is based on the most recent public health information and may be modified::: as necessary.  See the story and our post comments below for more info. ‚¨áÔ∏è  VTNEWS.VT.EDU Virginia Tech outlines its testing::: tracing::: and case management plan for the fall semester
column3: All employees & students will be required to complete an online COVID-19 awareness training program prior to arriving on a VT campus and will be strongly encouraged to complete a daily health verification survey. More details on the app and training program to come by Aug. 3.
column4: Students will be asked to self-quarantine and wear a face covering for 14 days before arriving on campus. Students are strongly encouraged to secure a negative PCR COVID-19 test result within 5 days prior to returning to the area. Those who test positive will be required to self-isolate before returning to a VT facility or location.
column5: On-campus students can be tested by Schiffert Health Center upon their arrival on campus during move-in. These students signed the Virginia Tech Housing & Residence Life COVID-19 Health and Well-being Commitment as part of their contract and will be expected to abide by these expectations. See more on that commitment here: https:// housing.vt.edu/ content/dam/ housing_vt_edu/ assets/doc/ Residential_Life _Health_and_Wel lbeing_Commitme nt.pdf
column6: Students and employees identified by VT as testing positive for COVID-19 will be reported to the Virginia Department of Health::: in accordance with the Code of Virginia. To ensure individual privacy::: individuals who test positive will not be publicly identified. Individuals who have tested positive::: are presumed positive::: or are identified by a public health professional or health care provider as a close contact::: should self-disclose to VT‚Äôs Case Management Team to contain the spread and provide additional support if necessary. Self-disclosure protocol details to come from this team.
column7: Students who test positive for COVID-19 should inform the Dean of Students Office (540-231-3787 or dean.students@v t.edu) and they will provide ongoing support for each student. VT will relocate on-campus students who test positive to New Hall West::: which will serve as the isolation residence hall::: where Hokies will receive daily health check calls from Schiffert Health Center staff.
column8: Employees are required to notify their supervisor if they must miss work due to illness or are asked to self-quarantine by the Virginia Department of Health. They should also report known university contacts and work locations to VT‚Äôs Case Management Team.

column18: This is hard to write. I do not think Virginia Tech should open this fall to on-campus classes. As much as I DEARLY want my daughter to have the whole college experience::: I do not think opening right now is the smartest decision::: when online classes::: though not as "good" will help to stop the spread of this virus and buy more time for more effective treatments and vaccines. Please don't let this be a financial decision on VT's part::: please. If one life is spared::: then there is no equivalent cost. Please remember::: VT and Blacksburg may be struggling financially due to Covid 19::: but so are the students and their parents::: whose jobs were reduced or eliminated. If you must open::: PLEASE re-organize your operations and take further::: even more unprecedented measures. -\-\- If you must open::: could students with lecture-only classes opt out of their housing contracts and take online classes from home? Doing so would free up dorm space for distancing. If you must open::: could students opt out of your mandatory meal plans so that they can keep themselves more safe and handle their own food? Do this would help your staff::: student workers::: and students simply be more safe. Yes::: such measures will affect your bottom line::: but no cost is too much to save lives. VT could graciously do more than what I have seen publicized.

Here's a closer look at what changes the fall semester will bring to Virginia Tech Dining Services. We are working to prioritize student and staff health as we navigate our plans::: with sanitation and safety as the guiding principles.  ‚û°Ô∏è Tables will be spaced nine feet apart to provide for six feet of physical distancing between people seated at different tables. Each table will be limited to four people and there will be reduced capacity in the buildings.  ‚û°Ô∏è Students in line must also observe physical distancing. We have installed ‚Äúmiles of plexiglass‚Äù to protect workers and those in serving lines. Hand sanitizer will be available at the entrance and throughout each building.  ‚û°Ô∏è We have installed touchless payment systems and self-service stations such as salad bars have been eliminated. Menus will be reduced::: but popular items such as chicken parmesan::: General Tso‚Äôs chicken::: and London broil will still be available.  ‚û°Ô∏è We are working closely with the Town of Blacksburg Government and area restaurants to make more options available to those without dining plans. We will also be increasing the number of food truck providers::: providing more ‚ÄúGrab-n-Gobble‚Äù options::: and expanding the number of Grubhub kiosks on campus.  ‚¨áÔ∏è Read more ‚¨áÔ∏è  VTNEWS.VT.EDU Changes coming to campus dining in fall 2020
